Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 08:53PM katiebug wrote: I haven't heard of that procedure.  You will be in my prayers.  Keep us posted.  Hope you will have a Merry Christmas, despite all that is going on.  (((hug)))
Posts.Title: Scared liveit56 liveit56

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 10:32AM katiebug wrote: Thanks, Rianne.  There are so many different results with everything...I wish there was a way to know what kind of result we will have before surgeries, etc.  I talked to my BS this morning and she is going to line up a consultation with a PS so that I can find out more info and discuss things with him/her.  I also asked about the breast MRI.  She'd rather wait until we get the genetic results, because if that comes back positive, I will choose to have a BMX, anyway.  She is not a big fan of the MRI because it often shows a lot of things that are nothing to worry about and then they are obligated to follow-up on each one.  She's not going to keep me from having it done, but she'd like to at least wait until the genetic test results since there was no area of concern on the mammo and no lumps have been felt.  I might consider having the BMX anyway, just so there will be no worry in the future and I won't have to have so many mammos, and that way my breasts could be even...since I'm having a MX anyway, I'd like to go up to a B from my nearly A :-), but I'm going to find out more info before I make my decision.  Some have had really good results and others, not so good.  Again, I wish there was a way to know what category I'll be in before I have the surgery.
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 06:52PM katiebug wrote: Thank you, SpecialK.  I meet with a PS next Thursday and am anxious to ask him a lot of questions!
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 05:16PM katiebug wrote: Thank you all.  It's good to read other people's experiences and their decisions and the results.  I've decided to definitely do a MX on my right breast with reconstruction.  I really want to know about my left breast, but since I can't find any lumps and nothing stands out on the mammo (it never does because I'm so dense and have always had scattered calcifications that were "normal" for me), they don't seem to be concerned about it, but I want to know.  I'm curious...what are your thoughts/experiences with breast MRIs...I know they can give false positives, but is it something I should request/ask about to hopefully get some peace of mind about my left breast?  If the genetic test comes back with the BRCA gene, I will definitely get a BMX, but if it doesn't, I'm still going to wonder.  I don't know how insurance works with prophylactic MX if the gene isn't present and there's no signs/symptoms of concern.  mybodymydecision, as far as pointers on having your boyfriend listen...I don't know...have you told him you really need to be able to talk to him about it, even if he doesn't know what to say?  Maybe he just doesn't know how to respond and so wants to avoid it?  Assure him that all you want right now is a listening ear and comfort.  My husband is a great listener, but doesn't always know what to say.  Just him listening and helping me talk through decisions helps a lot.  We've also been together for 15 years...married for 12...and have two children, so he is invested in making sure I get through this...he doesn't want me to leave him alone with the kids. =)  Try to let your boyfriend know you just need to talk to someone and all you need him to do for now is listen.  I hope that helps...wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 07:07PM katiebug wrote: Thank you both.  I'm calling my BS tomorrow to let her know what I decided and to get a recommendation for a PS to consult with for the reconstruction.  I will ask her about doing the MRI.  I would just feel better about it if it was looked at.  Would hate to have a MX on my right and then have a problem on my left in a couple of years and have to go through it all again.  It's not fun, as you all well know. I do not have a date for my surgery, yet.  I'm having the genetic test done on Thursday and I will be making an appt. to consult with a PS, so I probably won't have a date for a few weeks.  I hate the waiting game.  I'll be thinking of you mybodymydecision on the 27th...glad you can get through Christmas before having your surgery.  That was my kids' concern...they wanted me well for Christmas.  Keep us updated on how things go!
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: katiebug wrote: I was just diagnosed this month with DCIS.  It is stage 0 and slow growing, but it still scares me, even though I am told I'm "lucky" to have caught it early and will be just fine.  We were given basically two options for treatment, 1) lumpectomy followed by 6 weeks of radiation, or 2) mastectomy with reconstruction.  Neither one sounds fun.  I don't really want to go through radiation 5 days/week for 6 weeks.  The long recovery from a mastectomy also doesn't sound fun, especially with two young children, aged 6 and 8.  We are leaning toward the mastectomy because I don't want to take a chance that there is more cancer in other areas of my breast.  I have small, dense breasts that are hard to mammogram and not so easy to feel for lumps.  I've had 3 excisional biopsies in the same area of my right breast over the last 6 years...the first two turned out to be benign papillomas and now this third one is cancer.  Now I'm concerned there might be something in my left breast, even though I can't feel anything and nothing shows up on a mammo (not that it ever does with my breasts).  I am seeing a genetic counselor this week to take the test to see if I have the cancer gene.  As far as I know, there is no breast cancer in my family history, but there is other types of cancer.  If it comes back positive for the gene, I will most likely have a bilateral mastectomy. How do you make these decisions?  I am so overwhelmed as I read about each treatment and what others have experienced.  It is such a huge decision that can affect the rest of my life.  How did you make your treatment decisions...what helped you through this beginning time? Katiebug...feel free to read my blog of my journey in dealing with cancer: katie-myjourneytovictory.blogs... Dx 11/15/2011, DCIS, Stage 0, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 06:50PM katiebug wrote: Thank you all.  I think I will probably do the  mastectomy...that is the way my hubby and I have been leaning anyway.  My breasts are small (A), so a lumpectomy probably wouldn't leave much left, especially since a good amount has already been removed from my previous biopsies.  I've been reading the discussions about DIEP vs. implants.  So much more to this than I realized.  I know I want to have reconstruction...I don't think I'd do well mentally having no breast and a big scar...so many decisions.  Thank you all so much for sharing your experiences.  It's so nice to be able to "talk" to people who really understand.
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 08:26PM katiebug wrote: Thank you, ElenaMarie62 and Janetanned.  I am only 38 and although breast cancer does not run in my family, other cancers have.  I am going to request the MRI...what you went through, Janetanned, is exactly what I fear.  I do tend to worry and know I will always wonder about my left breast.  I am glad I have time to think it through and research.  I'm glad you are recovering well and hope you are as pleased with the results as they say you will be! That reminds me...I've read on different posts about a forum that has pictures of mastectomies and reconstructions...are those on this site, or are people finding them elsewhere on the internet?  I'd like to look at some pictures, but haven't found a tab or link for it on here.
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2011 12:04PM katiebug wrote: Hi Amy, I am also new here.  I was just diagnosed with stage 0 ductal carcinoma in situ.  Although it is "only" stage 0, I am scared about what faces me.  I'm meeting with a genetic counselor next Thursday to have the test done.  I am the first one, that I know of, diagnosed with breast cancer in my family.  There are other types of cancer on my mom's side, but not breast cancer.  I went through a few excisional biopsies of lumps that turned out to be benign papillomas over the last 6 years, but with this last one, the core needle biopsy came back with atypical cells and after the excisional biopsy, cancer was found.  I've been in shock and everything seems so surreal and scary at the same time.  I'm 38 years old and have a 8 year old and a 6 year old.  I'm making decisions about surgery with radiation, or total mastecomy(ies), depending on the genetic test results.  It is overwhelming.  I'm thankful for this sight, though, to be able to share with others going through it, too.  I wish you the best in your treatment!!
Posts.Title: Terrified. New here. AmyLB maryhelen

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 11:49AM katiebug wrote: Thank you for posting this thread and for all of those who have shared.  I feel badly for all of you!  I'll be having a BMX next month and am nervous about PMPS.  The information shared on here gives me some hope.  Best wishes to you all.
